article.headline: Brown rescues Panthers with clutch shooting
article.linkText: Pitt struggles vs. Rutgers, but remains unbeaten
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Jaron Brown's physical presence inside and ability to match up against stronger, bigger players has been an invaluable asset to nationally ranked Pitt for four seasons. He's now contributing from the outside, too. Brown scored 19 points and hit Pittsburgh's only two 3-pointers to key a late-game comeback that carried the 13th-ranked Panthers past Rutgers 59-49 Saturday. Pittsburgh, possibly looking ahead to Monday's game against No. 1 Connecticut, closed the game with a 16-2 run after the Scarlet Knights (9-5, 1-3 Big East) opened second-half leads of as many as six points. Pittsburgh (18-0, 4-0) extended its nation-best home court winning streak to 37 games, 31 at the Petersen Events Center. Jamie Dixon's 18-0 start is the third best by a rookie head coach in Division I history, according to Pitt research, trailing only the 33-0 by Indiana State's Bill Hodges in 1978-79 and Norman Shepard's 26-0 for North Carolina in 1923-24. Chris Taft, Pitt's 6-foot-10 freshman, had 17 points and 12 rebounds and teamed with Brown to lead the decisive finish, the third time in as many games Pitt has rallied to win after trailing in the second half. The Panthers denied they were thinking of UConn, though it didn't look that way for most of the first 30 minutes. "No, no, no," point guard Carl Krauser said. "Coach always prepares us for the game in front of us, we never look ahead. ... We always find a way to come back, because we've got great seniors to pull us through." That group includes Brown, who has improved his outside shooting even though he was only 4-of-32 on 3-pointers before Saturday. "That team must average 35 years old," Rutgers coach Gary Waters said. "They've been around and, when it comes down (to the end), they can look to themselves, they don't have to look to coach Dixon." Dixon wasn't surprised his players looked to Brown, who averages 12.7 points but often comes up with points at important times. Brown has 21, 16, 19 and 19 points in Pitt's four conference games. "He works so hard on his shooting, it's great to see him knock down shots like that," Dixon said. "He's in here working on his shooting before and after practice." Teammate Julius Page kept telling Brown to shoot and Brown, said, "I just let the shots come to me. They told me not to worry about my shooting percentage, to take my shot if it was there." Rutgers, trying for its second upset of a Top 25 team in as many Saturdays, led 47-43 with eight minutes left on Juel Wiggan's 15-footer, but scored only two more points. Herve Lamizana, Rutgers' top scorer with a 14.5 average, scored only six points while being guarded mostly by Brown. Rutgers, playing a ranked team for the third time in four games, has lost six straight to Pitt and is 1-4 on the road this season. The Knights were denied an even bigger upset than their 65-64 surprise win over No. 25 Providence on Jan. 10. Brown, coming off a 19-point game against Notre Dame, started the Panthers' comeback with a 3-pointer from the wing that cut Rutgers' lead to 47-46. Before then, Rutgers had ridden its 6-of-12 3-point shooting to take the lead, with Ricky Shields hitting a pair of 3s during a 10-0 run earlier in the half. Taft dunked to put Pitt up 48-47, then scored off a putback to make it 51-49 after Quincy Douby's basket tied it at 49 with just over four minutes left -- Rutgers' final points. Brown came up with two more key baskets after that, including another 3-pointer from the wing on a shot that seemed to be out of his range, jumping the lead to 57-49. Taft failed to score in double figures in three of Pitt's final four pre-Big East games, but is averaging 15.2 in conference play with three 17-point games. He'll match up Monday against 6-10 star Emeka Okafor when the Panthers take a 10-game conference winning streak to UConn. The Panthers beat Connecticut in their only two matchups last season, including a 74-56 decision in the Big East championship game.
